author: Richard
text:
5. The Hunger Games by Suzanne Collins
The Hunger Games takes place in remains of North America. Divided into 12 districts, 1 boy & 1 girl from each district must kill each - nationally televised, each year. The Games occur to remind the districts of their Capitol’s power. https://t.co/j6MtBmErHr

author: Richard
text:
4. Are You There God? It’s Me, Margaret by Judy Blume 
This book frequently faces challenges thanks to its portrayal of religion & detailed explanations of puberty & sexuality. This challenge even led some schools to require parental permission before students could read it.
👇🏻🧵 https://t.co/vXodyUWa7X

author: Richard
text:
3. The Catcher in the Rye by J.D. Salinger
Spanning only two days of Holden Caulfield’s- he sets out to find the truth in life by deciding to rebel against the “phoniness” of the adult world & faced issues for including prostitution and pre-marital sex.
👇🏻🧵 https://t.co/1xH1FhCHVp

author: Richard
text:
2. 1984 by George Orwell
Orwell’s dystopian novel follows Winston Smith, a low ranking member of “the Party.” Winston feels frustrated with the omnipresent eyes of “the Party” as well as the ominous ruler Big Brother who controls every aspect of individuals’ lives.
👇🏻🧵 https://t.co/KxxASq2lOE
